title: Trump’s Nomination for FEMA Chief Hits a Snag
text:
In his letter, Jeff Byard, associate administrator for the Office of Response and Recovery, said he would continue his service under the leadership of acting FEMA chief Peter Gaynor.

WASHINGTON— Jeffrey Byard, President Trump’s pick to head the Federal Emergency Management Agency, sought to withdraw his nomination last week after concerns about personal matters in his background were raised during the confirmation process.

In a letter to acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan dated Sept. 12, Mr. Byard wrote: “Over the past two years the Agency has seen a historic level of disaster activity and I feel it would be best for me to focus entirely on pressing issues related to my current role.”

Mr. Byard is currently serving as associate administrator for the Office of Response and Recovery. In his letter, he said he would continue his service under the leadership of acting FEMA chief Peter Gaynor.

The White House hasn’t yet announced the withdrawal of his nomination. The White House didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment on Mr. Byard’s letter, or to a question about whether Mr. Gaynor would be nominated as the agency’s permanent administrator. Flying back to Washington from California, Mr. Trump suggested he would keep Mr. Gaynor in his administrator role. “We think he would have been very good,” the president said of Mr. Byard, “but we’re also very happy with the man who’s acting, who has been acting.” Lawmakers in recent days had acknowledged problems with Mr. Byard’s nomination. Sen. Ron Johnson (R., Wis.), the chairman of the Senate committee that oversees FEMA, told Politico last week: “There were some issues raised that are being investigated and that’s all I’ll say about it." Hurricane Dorian Thrashes Bahamas With ‘Catastrophic’ Winds (Sept. 2)

FEMA to Further Restrict Puerto Rico’s Access to Relief Funds (July 25) A FEMA spokeswoman said Wednesday: “FEMA cannot comment on accusations made regarding a personal matter that allegedly occurred prior to Mr. Byard’s tenure with the Agency; however, Mr. Jeff Byard is a well-respected emergency manager and has honorably served as the Associate Administrator for the Office of Response and Recovery at FEMA for the past two years.” Axios first reported that Mr. Trump intended to withdraw Mr. Byard’s nomination and tap Mr. Gaynor in his place. The Trump administration’s last top disaster relief official, Brock Long, resigned in February after he came under fire for his unauthorized use of government vehicles. The Department of Homeland Security’s inspector general determined last September that Mr. Long cost the federal government $151,000 through the unauthorized use of government vehicles that included travel to his home in North Carolina and on a family vacation in Hawaii. Kirstjen Nielsen, the homeland security secretary at the time, ordered Mr. Long at the time to repay the government “as appropriate.” Write to Rebecca Ballhaus at Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.com
